unnormalised: The year was 2003. I remember it vividly. Sachin Tendulkar was at his peak, or so we thought back then. The Cricket World Cup was in South Africa, and the entire nation was glued to their TVs. The opening match for India was against the Netherlands on 12/02/2003. I was barely 10 yrs old, but the excitement was palpable even then.
normalised: The year was two thousand and three. I remember it vividly. Sachin Tendulkar was at his peak, or so we thought back then. The Cricket World Cup was in South Africa, and the entire nation was glued to their T-V-s. The opening match for India was against the Netherlands on twelfth february two thousand and three. I was barely ten years old, but the excitement was palpable even then.

unnormalised: My grandfather, a retired school teacher, meticulously wrote down the entire schedule in his diary. He’d mark the dates, times (IST, of course), and the expected outcomes. India vs Australia on 23/02/2003 at 9:30 AM was a big one. He predicted, with unwavering confidence, that India would win. Unfortunately, that didn't happen.
normalised: My grandfather, a retired school teacher, meticulously wrote down the entire schedule in his diary. He’d mark the dates, times (I-S-T, of course), and the expected outcomes. India versus Australia on twenty third february two thousand and three at nine thirty A-M was a big one. He predicted, with unwavering confidence, that India would win. Unfortunately, that didn't happen.

unnormalised: We’d gather around the television at 2:00 PM sharp every afternoon (or earlier, depending on the match timings). Chai and biscuits were mandatory. The laughter, the shouts, the collective groans after a dropped catch - it was a ritual. India vs Pakistan on 01/03/2003 at 2 PM was the most anticipated of them all. The atmosphere in the house was electric. My grandfather had even preponed his usual afternoon nap to watch the match.
normalised: We’d gather around the television at two zero zero P-M sharp every afternoon (or earlier, depending on the match timings). Chai and biscuits were mandatory. The laughter, the shouts, the collective groans after a dropped catch - it was a ritual. India versus Pakistan on first march two thousand and three at two P-M was the most anticipated of them all. The atmosphere in the house was electric. My grandfather had even preponed his usual afternoon nap to watch the match.

unnormalised: He would always remember the exact schedule of major tournaments. The Wimbledon finals on 06/07/2003 at 6:30 PM. The Australian Open finals on 26/01/2003. He knew them all. For him, it wasn't just about the sport; it was about the shared experience, the camaraderie, and the pure joy of watching the best in the world compete.
normalised: He would always remember the exact schedule of major tournaments. The Wimbledon finals on sixth july two thousand and three at six thirty P-M. The Australian Open finals on twenty sixth january two thousand and three. He knew them all. For him, it wasn't just about the sport; it was about the shared experience, the camaraderie, and the pure joy of watching the best in the world compete.

unnormalised: Then came the final on 23/03/2003. India vs Australia again. 1:30 PM IST. The hopes of a billion people rested on the shoulders of the Indian team. We all know how that turned out. But even in defeat, the spirit remained. My grandfather simply smiled and said, "There's always next time."
normalised: Then came the final on twenty third march two thousand and three. India versus Australia again. One thirty P-M I-S-T. The hopes of a billion people rested on the shoulders of the Indian team. We all know how that turned out. But even in defeat, the spirit remained. My grandfather simply smiled and said, "There's always next time."

unnormalised: Years later, I still remember those days. The neatly written schedule in his diary, the afternoon chai, and the unwavering belief in the Indian team. The ICC Cricket World Cup 2011 Final, India vs Sri Lanka on 02/04/2011 at 2:30 PM, brought back all those memories. This time, we won. And I couldn’t help but think of my grandfather, watching from somewhere, with a knowing smile.
normalised: Years later, I still remember those days. The neatly written schedule in his diary, the afternoon chai, and the unwavering belief in the Indian team. The I-C-C Cricket World Cup two thousand eleven Final, India versus Sri Lanka on second april two thousand and eleven at two thirty P-M, brought back all those memories. This time, we won. And I couldn’t help but think of my grandfather, watching from somewhere, with a knowing smile.

unnormalised: Now I keep a calendar of my own, updated with schedules for the Pro Kabaddi League games, the IPL, and the FIFA World Cup. I even mark out the timings for the local badminton tournament. It's my way of keeping the tradition alive, a tribute to the man who taught me that sports are more than just a game; they're a part of our lives, our culture, and our shared history. The upcoming Paris Olympics on 26/07/2024, which starts at 11:00 AM CEST (that's 2:30 PM IST) will be my first olympics without him, but I will still be sure to tune in.

The upcoming Paris Olympics on twenty sixth july two thousand and twenty four, which starts at eleven zero zero A-M C-E-S-T (that's two thirty P-M I-S-T) will be my first olympics without him, but I will still be sure to tune in.
